purpose.summary: This policy establishes the framework for recovering sales compensation payments that were made in error, based on inaccurate data, or where the underlying business transaction has been reversed or cancelled. This policy ensures Henry Schein maintains appropriate financial controls and protects against improper payments while maintaining fairness and transparency with sales team members.
objectives: Establish clear framework for recovering overpaid compensation
Maintain appropriate financial controls and protect against improper payments
Ensure fairness and transparency with sales team members
Comply with state wage law requirements
Provide structured approval authority based on clawback amounts

appliesTo: All sales compensation plans including commissions, bonuses, and incentive payments
All sales team members eligible for variable compensation
All Henry Schein divisions and business units in the United States
All clawback situations regardless of the amount (subject to minimum thresholds defined below)

definitions.definition: The recovery of previously paid sales compensation due to an error, reversal, cancellation, or other qualifying event as defined in this policy.
The difference between revenue and cost of goods sold for a transaction.
A sales transaction reversal that results in a gross profit adjustment exceeding $50,000.
The timeframe during which Henry Schein may pursue recovery of overpaid compensation, typically not exceeding 24 months from the original payment date.
An occurrence that initiates the clawback process as defined in Section 4 of this policy.

provisions.title: Clawback Triggering Events
provisions.content: Clawbacks may be initiated when one or more of the following events occur:

subProvisions.title: Revenue Reversals and Cancellations
subProvisions.content: When a sales transaction is reversed, cancelled, or returned, resulting in a gross profit adjustment of $50,000 or more.
items: Customer order cancellations after commission payment
Product returns that reduce the original transaction value
Credit memos issued for quality, pricing, or delivery issues
Contract terminations or rescissions

subProvisions.title: Data or Calculation Errors
subProvisions.content: When compensation was paid based on incorrect data or miscalculations, including:
items: System errors in commission calculation engines
Incorrect crediting or double-crediting of sales
Manual processing errors
Incorrect application of commission rates or plan rules

subProvisions.title: Compliance Violations
subProvisions.content: When compensation was earned through actions that violate company policy or legal requirements:
items: Sales obtained through fraudulent means
Violations of company code of conduct
Breach of sales crediting policies
Conflict of interest violations

subProvisions.title: Bad Debt and Non-Payment
subProvisions.content: When customer payment is not received within 180 days of invoice date, or when accounts are written off as uncollectible. Clawback provisions apply when:
items: Invoice remains unpaid after 180 days
Account is sent to collections
Bad debt reserve is applied
Customer enters bankruptcy proceedings

provisions.content: Clawback approvals require different levels of authority based on the amount:

provisions.title: Recovery Mechanisms
provisions.content: Henry Schein will use the following methods to recover overpaid compensation, listed in order of preference:

subProvisions.title: Payroll Deduction (Primary Method)
subProvisions.content: For active employees, recovery through payroll deduction is the preferred method. Key provisions:
items: Maximum deduction per pay period: 25% of net variable compensation
Minimum deduction amount: $500 per pay period (if balance exceeds $2,000)
Employee will receive 60-day advance written notice before deductions begin
Recovery plan must be completed within 12 months unless special circumstances exist
State wage law requirements will be followed for all deductions

subProvisions.title: Voluntary Repayment Agreement
subProvisions.content: Employees may opt for a voluntary repayment schedule as an alternative to payroll deduction:
items: Written repayment agreement signed by employee and company
Payment schedule negotiated based on amount owed and employee circumstances
Minimum monthly payment of $500 or 10% of outstanding balance, whichever is greater
Interest may be charged at company's cost of capital rate on balances exceeding $10,000

subProvisions.title: Offset Against Future Payments
subProvisions.content: Recovery may be achieved by reducing future commission or bonus payments:
items: Applied when current period has insufficient compensation for payroll deduction
May be used in combination with payroll deduction
Employee must be notified in writing before offset is applied

subProvisions.title: Final Paycheck Recovery
subProvisions.content: For terminated employees, recovery from final compensation payments:
items: Subject to state law requirements regarding final pay deductions
Requires written authorization in states that mandate employee consent
May not reduce final pay below minimum wage requirements

subProvisions.title: Direct Payment Request
subProvisions.content: When other methods are not available or practical:
items: Written demand for payment sent via certified mail
30-day payment deadline from date of notice
May pursue legal action if payment is not received

provisions.title: Notification and Communication Requirements
provisions.content: Comprehensive communication protocol to ensure transparency and fairness.

subProvisions.title: Initial Notice (60-Day Advance)
subProvisions.content: When a clawback is identified, the employee must receive written notice including:
items: Detailed explanation of the triggering event
Specific amount subject to recovery
Calculation methodology showing how the amount was determined
Proposed recovery method and schedule
Employee's right to appeal
Contact information for questions

subProvisions.title: Recovery Commencement Notice
subProvisions.content: At least 15 days before recovery begins, employee receives confirmation stating:
items: Start date of recovery
Amount per pay period (if payroll deduction)
Expected completion date
Running balance tracking method

subProvisions.title: Ongoing Communication
subProvisions.content: Continuous updates throughout recovery process:
items: Monthly statements showing remaining balance
Itemized deduction details on pay stubs
Confirmation letter when recovery is complete

provisions.title: Tracking and Documentation Requirements
provisions.content: The Sales Compensation team must maintain comprehensive records of all clawbacks.

subProvisions.title: Clawback Register
subProvisions.content: A centralized tracking system that includes:
items: Unique clawback case ID
Employee name and ID
Date clawback identified
Triggering event category
Original payment date and amount
Amount subject to recovery
Approval chain and dates
Recovery method and schedule
Amount recovered to date
Outstanding balance
Status (Active, Complete, Appealed, Forgiven)

subProvisions.title: Supporting Documentation
subProvisions.content: Each clawback case file must contain:
items: Original transaction documentation
Calculation worksheets
All employee notifications (with delivery confirmation)
Approval signatures
Legal review documentation (if applicable)
Appeal documents (if applicable)
Recovery confirmation

subProvisions.title: Retention Period
subProvisions.content: All clawback documentation must be retained for seven (7) years following the date of final recovery or case closure, in accordance with Henry Schein's data retention policy and applicable legal requirements.

provisions.title: Appeals Process
provisions.content: Employees have the right to appeal any clawback decision. The appeals process provides a fair mechanism to address disputed clawbacks.

subProvisions.title: Filing an Appeal
subProvisions.content: Requirements and timeline for submitting an appeal:
items: Employee must submit written appeal within 30 days of initial notification
Appeal must include specific reasons for disputing the clawback
Supporting documentation must be provided
Recovery is typically suspended during the appeal process

subProvisions.title: Appeal Review Process
subProvisions.content: Appeals are reviewed by a three-person committee consisting of: Director of Sales Compensation (or designee), HR Business Partner, and Finance Representative. The committee will:
items: Review all documentation within 15 business days
Conduct employee interview if requested
Issue written decision with rationale
Recommend affirmation, modification, or reversal of clawback

subProvisions.title: Final Appeal
subProvisions.content: If the employee disagrees with the committee's decision, a final appeal may be made to the Compensation Review Board within 15 days. The Board's decision is final.

provisions.title: Special Circumstances and Exceptions
provisions.content: Provisions for handling exceptional cases and hardship situations.

subProvisions.title: Hardship Consideration
subProvisions.content: In cases of demonstrated financial hardship, employees may request:
items: Extended repayment period (up to 24 months)
Reduced payment amounts
Temporary suspension of recovery (up to 90 days)

subProvisions.title: Small Balance Write-Offs
subProvisions.content: Clawback amounts under $100 may be written off at the discretion of the Sales Compensation Manager when the cost of recovery exceeds the amount owed.

subProvisions.title: Deceased or Disabled Employees
subProvisions.content: Special provisions apply in cases of employee death or permanent disability. Legal counsel must be consulted before pursuing recovery in these situations.

subProvisions.title: Statute of Limitations
subProvisions.content: Henry Schein will not pursue clawbacks more than 24 months from the original payment date, except in cases of fraud or intentional misconduct where longer statutory periods may apply.

provisions.title: Roles and Responsibilities
provisions.content: Clearly defined roles for all parties involved in the clawback process.

subProvisions.title: Sales Compensation Team
subProvisions.content: Primary responsibilities:
items: Identify clawback triggering events through monthly data reviews
Calculate accurate recovery amounts
Prepare clawback notifications and documentation
Maintain clawback register and tracking system
Process appeals and coordinate with review committees
Ensure compliance with notification timelines

subProvisions.title: Finance Department
subProvisions.content: Financial oversight and processing:
items: Review and validate financial data supporting clawbacks over $5,000
Provide approval for clawbacks exceeding $25,000
Process payroll deductions and track recovery progress
Reconcile recovered amounts to general ledger

subProvisions.title: Legal Department
subProvisions.content: Legal compliance and review:
items: Review clawback actions exceeding $25,000
Ensure compliance with state wage laws
Approve clawback language in employment agreements
Advise on complex cases involving terminated employees or legal disputes

subProvisions.title: Human Resources
subProvisions.content: Employee relations support:
items: Participate in appeals review committee
Evaluate hardship requests
Ensure fair and consistent application of policy
Address employee relations concerns

subProvisions.title: Sales Management
subProvisions.content: Front-line support and communication:
items: Communicate policy to sales teams
Notify Sales Compensation of potential triggering events
Support employees through the clawback process
Provide context for appeals when appropriate

provisions.title: Policy Review and Updates
provisions.content: This policy will be reviewed annually by the Sales Compensation Governance Committee and updated as needed to reflect changes in business practices, legal requirements, or organizational structure. All substantive changes require approval by Legal, Finance, and HR leadership.
